Subsection.Text: The Minister may, in respect of a medical device in relation to which investigational testing is being conducted, request the manufacturer or importer of the device to submit information in respect of the testing if the Minister believes on reasonable grounds, after reviewing a report or information brought to the Minister’s attention, that one of the following conditions may exist:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the testing seriously endangers the life, health or safety of patients, users or other persons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the testing is contrary to the best interests of patients on whom the testing is being conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the objective of the testing will not be achieved;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the qualified investigator who is conducting the testing is not respecting the undertaking required by paragraph 81(k); or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the information submitted in respect of the testing is false or misleading.

Subsection.Text: If the information requested pursuant to subsection (1) is not submitted, or if it is submitted and the Minister determines after reviewing it that a condition identified in that subsection exists, the Minister may, by written notice giving reasons,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Class I device, direct the manufacturer or importer of the device to stop selling the device to any qualified investigator named in the notice; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a Class II, III or IV device, cancel the authorization referred to in subsection 83(1), in whole or in part.

Section.Text: No person shall import or sell a medical device for investigational testing unless the device has a label that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the statements “Investigational Device” and “Instrument de recherche”, or any other statement, in English and French, that conveys that meaning;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the statements “To Be Used by Qualified Investigators Only” and “Réservé uniquement à l’usage de chercheurs compétents”, or any other statement, in English and French, that conveys that meaning; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an IVDD, the statements “The performance specifications of this device have not been established” and “Les spécifications de rendement de l’instrument n’ont pas été établies”, or any other statement, in English and French, that conveys that meaning.

Section.Text: No person shall advertise a medical device that is the subject of investigational testing unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that person holds an authorization issued under subsection 83(1) to sell or import the device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the advertisement clearly indicates that the device is the subject of investigational testing, and the purpose of the investigational testing.

Section.Text: The requirements set out in the following provisions apply to medical devices to which this Part applies:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 52 to 56 with respect to distribution records;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sections 57 and 58 with respect to complaint handling;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sections 59 to 61.1 with respect to reports on incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: sections 63 to 65.1 with respect to recalls; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: sections 66 to 68 with respect to implant registration.

Section.Text: Subsections 61.2(2) and (3) and section 61.3 apply in respect of medical devices to which this Part applies except that the references to a holder of a therapeutic product authorization in those provisions shall be read as references to a holder of an authorization issued under subsection 83(1).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of section 37 of the Act, Schedule 3 sets out the form to be used for an export certificate for medical devices.
The export certificate shall be signed and dated by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the exporter of the device is a corporation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the exporter’s senior executive officer in Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the exporter’s senior regulatory officer in Canada, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the authorized agent of the person referred to in subparagraph (i) or (ii); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the exporter of the device is an individual,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the exporter, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the exporter’s authorized agent.

Section.Text: No person shall sign an export certificate that is false or misleading or that contains omissions that may affect its accuracy and completeness.

The exporter of a device shall maintain, at their principal place of business in Canada, records that contain the completed export certificates and shall, when requested to do so by an inspector, submit the export certificates for examination.
The exporter of a device shall retain the export certificate for a period of not less than five years after the date of export.

Heading.Label: PART 5
Heading.TitleText: Transitional Provisions, Repeal and Coming into Force

Section.Text: For the purposes of sections 94 and 95, old regulations means the Medical Devices Regulations, C.R.C., c. 871, and Director has the meaning assigned to it by those regulations.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), if an application for a notice of compliance has been submitted with respect to a medical device pursuant to Part V of the old regulations but has not been processed by the Director as of June 30, 1998, an application for a medical device licence shall be made pursuant to these Regulations.

For the purposes of an application for a medical device licence, the information and documents required by paragraphs 32(2)(a) to (e), (3)(a) to (i) or (4)(a) to (o) are deemed to have been submitted if a notice of compliance with respect to the device had been issued under the old regulations.
A medical device that, on June 30, 1998, is being sold in Canada pursuant to the old regulations is not required to be licensed until February 1, 1999, if,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device that is subject to Part V of the old regulations, the manufacturer

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has a notice of compliance in respect of the device that is in effect on June 30, 1998, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: does not have a notice of compliance in respect of the device that is in effect on June 30, 1998, but has met, during the period beginning on October 8, 1982, and ending on March 31, 1983, the requirements for device notification pursuant to Part II of the old regulations in respect of the device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device that is not subject to Part V of the old regulations, the manufacturer has, by June 30, 1998, furnished the Director with the notification required in subsection 24(1) of the old regulations in respect of the device.

Subsection.Text: If an initial application for licensing of a medical device that is referred to in subsection (1) is submitted before February 1, 1999, the information and documents required by paragraphs 32(2)(a) to (e), (3)(a) to (i) or (4)(a) to (o) are deemed to have been submitted if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device that is subject to Part V of the old regulations, the manufacturer

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: has a notice of compliance in respect of the device that is in effect on June 30, 1998, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: does not have a notice of compliance that is in effect on June 30, 1998, in respect of the device, but has met, during the period beginning on October 8, 1982, and ending on March 31, 1983, the requirements for device notification pursuant to Part II of the old regulations in respect of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device that is not subject to Part V of the old regulations, the manufacturer has, by June 30, 1998, furnished the Director with the notification required in subsection 24(1) of the old regulations in respect of the device.

Subsection.Text: Subsections (1) and (2) cease to apply in respect of a medical device if a change described in section 34 is made in respect of the device or if the notice of compliance is suspended or cancelled under section 40 of the old regulations.
For the purposes of this section, a notice of compliance may be suspended or cancelled under section 40 of the old regulations as if that section were still in force.

Section.Text: [Repeal]

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) to (5), these Regulations come into force on July 1, 1998.
Section 32, except paragraphs (2)(f), (3)(j) and (4)(p), comes into force

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a medical device referred to in section 94 or 95, on September 1, 1998;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of any other medical device, on July 1, 1998.

Subsection.Text: Paragraphs 32(2)(f), (3)(j) and (4)(p) come into force on January 1, 2003.
Sections 43 and 44 come into force on January 1, 1999.
Sections 45 to 51 come into force on November 1, 1998.

Heading.Label: PART 1
Heading.TitleText: Medical Devices other than in Vitro Diagnostic Devices

Provision.Text: Rule 1:
Subject to subrules (2) and (3), all surgically invasive devices are classified as Class II.

A surgically invasive device that is intended to diagnose, monitor, control or correct a defect of the central cardiovascular system or the central nervous system or of a fetus in utero is classified as Class IV.
A surgically invasive device that is intended to be absorbed by the body, or that is normally intended to remain in the body for at least 30 consecutive days, is classified as Class III.
Rule 2:
Subject to subrules (2) to (4), all invasive devices that penetrate the body through a body orifice or that come into contact with the surface of the eye are classified as Class II.
A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to be placed in the oral or nasal cavities as far as the pharynx or in the ear canal up to the ear drum is classified as Class I.
A device described in subrule (1) that is normally intended to remain in the body or in contact with the surface of the eye for at least 30 consecutive days is classified as Class III.

A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to be represented as preventing the transmission of infectious agents during sexual activities or reducing the risk thereof is classified as Class III.
Rule 3:
Despite rules 1 and 2

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: all denture materials and orthodontic appliances, and their accessories, are classified as Class II;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: all surgical or dental instruments are classified as Class I; and

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: all latex condoms are classified as Class II.
Rule 4:
Subject to subrule (2), all non-invasive devices that are intended to come into contact with injured skin are classified as Class II.
A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to be used as a mechanical barrier, for compression or for absorption of exudations, is classified as Class I.
Rule 5:

A non-invasive device intended for channelling or storing gases, liquids, tissues or body fluids for the purpose of introduction into the body by means of infusion or other means of administration is classified as Class II.
Rule 6:

Subject to subrules (2) and (3), a non-invasive device intended for modifying the biological or chemical composition of blood or other body fluids, or liquids, for the purpose of introduction into the body by means of infusion or other means of administration is classified as Class III.

A device described in subrule (1) whose characteristics are such that the modification process may introduce a foreign substance into the body that is potentially hazardous, taking into account the nature and quantity of the substance, is classified as Class IV.
A device described in subrule (1) that accomplishes the modification by centrifugation, gravity filtration or the exchange of gas or heat is classified as Class II.
Rule 7:
Subject to subrule (2), all other non-invasive devices are classified as Class I.
A device described in subrule (1) is classified as Class II if it is intended

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: to act as a calibrator, tester or quality control support to another medical device; or

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: to be connected to an active device that is classified as Class II, III or IV.
Rule 8:

Subject to subrules (2) and (3), an active device intended to emit ionizing radiation, including any device or software intended to control or monitor such a device or directly influence its performance, is classified as Class III.
A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to be used in radiographic mode is classified as Class II.
Despite subrule (2), an active device that is intended to be used for mammographies is classified as Class III.
Rule 9:
Subject to subrules (2) and (3), an active therapeutic device, including any dedicated software, intended to be used to administer or withdraw energy to or from the body is classified as Class II.

If the administration or withdrawal by a device described in subrule (1) is potentially hazardous, taking into account the nature of the administration or withdrawal, the intensity of the energy and the part of the body concerned, the device is classified as Class III.
A device described in subrule (2) that is intended to control the treatment of a patient’s condition through a closed loop system is classified as Class IV.
Rule 10:
Subject to subrule (2), an active diagnostic device, including any dedicated software, that supplies energy for the purpose of imaging or monitoring physiological processes is classified as Class II.

A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to be used to monitor, assess or diagnose a disease, a disorder, an abnormal physical state or a pregnancy, if erroneous readings could result in immediate danger, is classified as Class III.
Rule 11:

Subject to subrules (2) and (3), an active device, including any dedicated software, intended to administer drugs, body fluids or other substances to the body or withdraw them from the body is classified as Class II.

If the administration or withdrawal by a device described in subrule (1) is potentially hazardous, taking into account the nature of the administration or withdrawal, the nature of the substance involved and the part of the body concerned, the device is classified as Class III.
A device described in subrule (2) that is intended to control the treatment of a patient’s condition through a closed loop system is classified as Class IV.
Rule 12:
Any other active device is classified as Class I.
Rule 13:
A medical device that is intended to be used for

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: disinfecting or sterilizing blood, tissues or organs that are intended for transfusion or transplantation is classified as Class IV; and

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: disinfecting or sterilizing a medical device is classified as Class II.
Rule 14:
Subject to subrule (2), the following medical devices are classified as Class IV:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: a medical device that is manufactured from or that incorporates human or animal cells or tissues or their derivatives; and

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: a medical device that is manufactured from or that incorporates a product produced through the use of recombinant DNA technology.
A device described in subrule (1) that is intended to come into contact with intact skin only is classified as Class I.
Rule 15:

Any medical device that is a material intended to be sold to a health care professional or dispenser for the specific purpose of configuration or arrangement into a mould or shape to meet the needs of an individual is classified in the class that applies to the finished medical device.
Rule 16:
Despite rules 1 to 15, a medical device set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this rule is classified as the class set out in column 2 of that item.

row.entry: Tissue expanders for breast reconstruction and augmentation

Heading.TitleText: Use with respect to Transmissible Agents

Provision.Text: Rule 1:

An IVDD that is intended to be used to detect the presence of, or exposure to, a transmissible agent in blood, blood components, blood derivatives, tissues or organs to assess their suitability for transfusion or transplantation is classified as Class IV.
Rule 2:
An IVDD that is intended to be used to detect the presence of, or exposure to, a transmissible agent is classified as Class II, unless

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used to detect the presence of, or exposure to, a transmissible agent that causes a life-threatening disease if there is a risk of propagation in the Canadian population, in which case it is classified as Class IV; or

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: it falls into one of the following categories, in which case it is classified as Class III:

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used to detect the presence of, or exposure to, a transmissible agent that causes a serious disease where there is a risk of propagation in the Canadian population,

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used to detect the presence of, or exposure to, a sexually transmitted agent,

Provision.Label: (iii)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used to detect the presence of an infectious agent in cerebrospinal fluid or blood, or

Provision.Label: (iv)
Provision.Text: there is a risk that an erroneous result would cause death or severe disability to the individual being tested, or to the individual’s offspring.
Rule 3:
An IVDD that is intended to be used for patient management is classified as Class II, unless it falls into one of the following categories, in which case it is classified as Class III:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used for the management of patients suffering from a life-threatening disease; or

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: there is a risk that an erroneous result will lead to a patient management decision resulting in an imminent life-threatening situation for the patient.
Rule 4:

An IVDD that is not subject to rules 1 to 3 and that is intended to be used in diagnosis or patient management is classified as Class II, unless it falls into one of the following categories, in which case it is classified as Class III:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used in screening for or in the diagnosis of cancer;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used for genetic testing;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used in screening for congenital disorders in the fetus;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: there is a risk that an erroneous diagnostic result would cause death or severe disability to the patient being tested or to that patient’s offspring;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used for disease staging; or

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: it is intended to be used to monitor levels of drugs, substances or biological components, if there is a risk that an erroneous result will lead to a patient management decision resulting in an imminent life-threatening situation for the patient.
Rule 5:

An IVDD that is intended to be used for blood grouping or tissue typing to ensure the immunological compatibility of blood, blood components, tissue or organs that are intended for transfusion or transplantation is classified as Class III.
Rule 6:
A near patient IVDD is classified as Class III.
Rule 7:

In cases where an IVDD, including its analyzers, reagents and software, is intended to be used with another IVDD, the class of both IVDDs will be that of the IVDD in the class representing the higher risk.
Rule 8:
If rules 1 to 7 do not apply, all other IVDDs are classified as Class I.
Rule 9:
Despite rules 1 to 8, an IVDD set out in column 1 of an item of the table to this rule is classified as the class set out in column 2 of that item.

Section.Text: The manufacturer of a medical device for which a medical device licence has been issued before the coming into force of these Regulations shall, before November 1, 2003, submit to the Minister, together with the statement required by subsection 43(1) of the Medical Devices Regulations, a copy of the quality system certificate referred to in paragraph 32(2)(f), (3)(j) or (4)(p) of those Regulations, as applicable.]

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection 43.12(1) of the Medical Devices Regulations, information in respect of a clinical study or investigational testing, as defined in section 43.11 of those Regulations, that is confidential business information and that is contained in an application with respect to which one of the following circumstances occurred before the day on which these Regulations come into force ceases to be confidential business information on the day on which these Regulations come into force:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister issued a licence under paragraph 36(1)(a) of the Medical Devices Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister amended a licence under paragraph 36(1)(b) of the Medical Devices Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister refused to issue or amend a licence under section 38 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to information referred to in subsection 43.12(2) of the Medical Devices Regulations.

In this section and in sections 11 to 15, Exceptional Importation and Shortages Interim Order No. 2 means the Interim Order No. 2 Respecting Drugs, Medical Devices and Foods for a Special Dietary Purpose in Relation to COVID-19, made by the Minister of Health on March 1, 2021 and published in Part I of the Canada Gazette on March 20, 2021.

In sections 11 to 15, designated biocide, designated drug, designated food for a special dietary purpose, designated hand sanitizer and designated medical device have the same meaning as in the Exceptional Importation and Shortages Interim Order No. 2.
Section 62.31 of the Medical Devices Regulations applies in respect of a designated medical device that was imported under the Exceptional Importation and Shortages Interim Order No. 2.
Section 62.32 of those Regulations applies to the holder of an establishment licence in respect of a designated medical device that they imported under that Interim Order.

Section.Text: A person who, immediately before the Exceptional Importation and Shortages Interim Order No. 2 ceased to have effect, was permitted, under subsection 30(2) of that Interim Order, to conduct an activity in respect of a designated hand sanitizer may continue to do so without holding an establishment licence that authorizes them to do so until the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the occurrence of one of the circumstances referred to in paragraphs 30(2)(a) to (c) of that Interim Order, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: September 1, 2023.

Subsection.Text: In sections 11 to 19, Interim Order No. 3 means Interim Order No. 3 Respecting the Importation and Sale of Medical Devices for Use in Relation to COVID-19, made by the Minister on February 21, 2022 and published in the Canada Gazette, Part I, on March 12, 2022.
Unless the context requires otherwise, words and expressions used in sections 11 to 19 have the same meaning as in the Medical Devices Regulations.

For the purposes of sections 11 to 19, a reference to “instrument médical destiné à être utilisé à l’égard de la COVID-19” in the French version of Interim Order No. 3 and the List of Medical Devices for Expanded Use in Relation to the COVID-19 Pandemic shall be read as “instrument médical contre la COVID-19”.

Section.Text: Despite subsection 68.11(1) of the Medical Devices Regulations, an application for an authorization for importation or sale of a COVID-19 medical device that was submitted to the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force and in respect of which no decision has been made before that day is deemed to be an application for an authorization submitted under section 68.11 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

Subsection.Text: An authorization for importation or sale of a COVID-19 medical device that was issued by the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force and has not been cancelled before that day is deemed to be an authorization issued under section 68.12 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

Any terms and conditions of an authorization for importation or sale referred to in subsection (1) are deemed to have been imposed by the Minister under section 68.19 of the Medical Devices Regulations on the other authorization referred to in that subsection.

Section.Text: A COVID-19 medical device for which the manufacturer of the device holds an authorization and that is not labelled in accordance with subsection 21(2) of the Medical Devices Regulations in the six-month period that begins on the day on which these Regulations come into force the device may, despite that subsection, be sold during that period.

Section 68.35 of the Medical Devices Regulations shall be read without reference to subsection 21(2) of those Regulations in regard to any portion of the period referred to in that section that falls within the period referred to in section 13.

An application to amend an authorization for importation or sale of a COVID-19 medical device that was submitted to the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force and in respect of which no decision has been made before that day is deemed to be an application to amend an authorization submitted under section 68.14 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

An authorization for importation or sale of a COVID-19 medical device that was amended by the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force and has not been cancelled before that day is deemed to be an authorization that is amended to the same extent under section 68.15 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

A request that was made by the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force for additional information or material, including samples, is deemed to be a request for additional information or material under section 68.23 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a COVID-19 medical device that is not a UPHN medical device on the day on which these Regulations come into force, a reference in subparagraphs 68.21(1)(h)(i), (i)(i) and (ii) and (j)(i) and (ii) of the Medical Devices Regulations to “the device ceases to be a UPHN medical device” shall be read as “the Regulations Amending the Medical Devices Regulations (Interim Order No. 3 Respecting the Importation and Sale of Medical Devices for Use in Relation to COVID-19) come into force”.
Subsection (1) ceases to apply in respect of a COVID-19 medical device referred to in that subsection if the device becomes a UPHN medical device.

Section.Text: A request that was made by the Minister under Interim Order No. 3 before the day on which these Regulations come into force for information in relation to the expanded use of a COVID-19 medical device or another medical device set out in the List of Medical Devices for Expanded Use in Relation to the COVID-19 Pandemic, referred to in the definition List of Medical Devices for Expanded Use in subsection 1(1) of the Interim Order, is deemed to be a request for information in relation to the expanded use under subsection 68.38(1) or (2) of the Medical Devices Regulations, as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: In this section, authorization has the same meaning as in section 68.01 of the Medical Devices Regulations.

In respect of an authorization for a medical device that is issued before the day on which these Regulations come into force, paragraph 68.17(a) of the Medical Devices Regulations is to be read as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: COVID-19;

Subsection.Text: Section 68.17 of the Medical Devices Regulations, as it read immediately before the day on which these Regulations come into force, applies in respect of an application to amend an authorization that was submitted under section 68.14 of the Medical Devices Regulations before the day on which these Regulations come into force and in respect of which no decision has been made before that day.

Section.Text: The Medical Devices Regulations2 are amended by adding the following after section 2:
For greater certainty, these Regulations apply to a medical device that is a drug referred to in paragraph (b) or (c) of the definition biocide in subsection 1(1) of the Biocides Regulations.
The definition recall in section 1 of the Medical Devices Regulations2 is replaced by the following:

Definition.Text: recall means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a recall ordered by the Minister under section 21.3 of the Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any action taken by a manufacturer, importer or distributor of a medical device, after the device has been sold, to recall or correct the device, or to notify its owners and users of its defectiveness or potential defectiveness, after becoming aware that the device

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: may present a risk of injury to health,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: may fail to conform to any claim made by the manufacturer or importer relating to its effectiveness, benefits, performance characteristics or safety, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: may not meet the requirements of the Act or these Regulations. (rappel)

Section.Text: Paragraph 45(b) of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: any other name under which the person previously conducted activities under these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, title and contact information of the representative of the establishment to contact for information concerning the application;

Section.Text: Section 48 of the English version of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

If, following the issuance of an establishment licence, there is a change to any of the information referred to in paragraph 45(a) or (b), the holder of the establishment licence shall submit the new information to the Minister within 15 days of the change.
The Regulations are amended by adding the following after section 48:
The Minister may, at any time, impose terms and conditions on an establishment licence, or amend those terms and conditions, after considering the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether there are uncertainties relating to the manner in which an activity is or will be conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the requirements under the Act are sufficient to protect patients, users or other persons from risks to health or safety;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether compliance with the proposed terms and conditions is feasible; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether there are less burdensome ways to meet the objectives of the proposed terms and conditions.

Section.Text: Section 53 of the Regulations is replaced by the following:
The distribution record shall contain sufficient information to permit the complete and rapid recall of the medical device.
Subsection 62.31(1) of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: The provisions of these Regulations — other than this section and sections 44 to 62.2 and 62.32 to 65.6 — do not apply to the sale of a designated medical device that is imported under section 62.29.

Section.Text: The heading before section 63 of the English version of the Regulations is replaced by the following:
The Regulations are amended by adding the following before section 63:
The portion of section 63 of the Regulations before paragraph (a) is replaced by the following:
Sections 63.2, 64 and 65 do not apply to
The Regulations are amended by adding the following after section 63:

Sections 63.2, 64 and 65 do not apply to a manufacturer or importer of a medical device unless the device is likely to cause injury to the health of a patient, user or other person, or could cause serious injury to the health of a patient, user or other person.

A manufacturer or importer of a medical device who decides to recall the device without being ordered to do so by the Minister shall provide the Minister with the following information, in writing, within 24 hours after making the decision:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identifier of the device, including the identifier of any medical device that is part of a system, test kit, medical device group, medical device family or medical device group family;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed device, the medical device licence number;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device for which the manufacturer holds an authorization issued under section 68.12, the authorization number;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the establishment where the device was manufactured, if different from that of the manufacturer, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the importer;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the recall, the nature of the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device and the date on which and the circumstances under which the defectiveness or potential defectiveness was discovered; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a preliminary evaluation of the risk associated with the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device.

Section.Text: Section 64 of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

A manufacturer or importer of a medical device shall, on or before the day on which the manufacturer or importer begins a recall of the device that has not been ordered by the Minister, provide the Minister with the following information and documents in writing:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identifier of the device, including the identifier of any medical device that is part of a system, test kit, medical device group, medical device family or medical device group family;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed device, the medical device licence number;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device for which the manufacturer holds an authorization issued under section 68.12, the authorization number;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the establishment where the device was manufactured, if different from that of the manufacturer, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the importer;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the recall, the nature of the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device and the date on which and the circumstances under which the defectiveness or potential defectiveness was discovered;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the risk associated with the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the number of affected units of the device that the manufacturer or importer

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: manufactured in Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: imported into Canada, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: sold in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the affected units of the device were distributed in Canada by the manufacturer or importer;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person to whom the affected device was sold by the manufacturer or importer and the number of units of the device sold to each person;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any communication issued with respect to the recall;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed strategy for conducting the recall, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date for beginning the recall,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time and manner in which the Minister will be informed of the progress of the recall, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the proposed date of its completion;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed action to prevent a recurrence of the problem; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the name, title and contact information of the representative of the manufacturer or importer to contact for information concerning the recall.

Section.Text: The portion of section 65 of the Regulations before paragraph (a) is replaced by the following:

A manufacturer or importer of a medical device shall, within 30 days after completing a recall of the device that was not ordered by the Minister, provide the Minister with the following information, in writing:
Section 65.1 of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: A manufacturer of a medical device who recalls the device without being ordered to do so by the Minister may permit the importer of the device to prepare and submit, on the manufacturer’s behalf, the information and documents that are required to be provided under sections 63.2, 64 and 65 if the information and documents that the manufacturer and importer must submit are identical.

The manufacturer shall advise the Minister in writing if the manufacturer has permitted the importer to prepare and submit the information and documents referred to in subsection (1) on the manufacturer’s behalf.
A person who is ordered by the Minister to recall a medical device shall provide the Minister with the following information in the time and manner specified by the Minister:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturer of the device,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the establishment where the device was manufactured, if different from that of the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the importer of the device, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the person who sold them the device, if the person who is conducting the recall is not the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device and the date on which and the circumstances under which the defectiveness or potential defectiveness was discovered;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of affected units of the device that the person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: manufactured in Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: imported into Canada, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: sold in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of affected units of the device in Canada that are in the possession or control of the person;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the affected units of the device were distributed in Canada by the person;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of affected units of the device that have been sold by the person at the retail level to consumers in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the person has sold the affected device to persons in Canada other than consumers referred to in paragraph (f), the names of those persons and the number of units of the device sold to each of them;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed strategy for conducting the recall, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date for beginning the recall,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the time and manner in which the Minister will be informed of the progress of the recall, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the proposed date of its completion;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the proposed action to prevent a recurrence of the problem;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the name, title and contact information of the representative of the person to contact for information concerning the recall; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: any other information that the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe is necessary to reduce the risk of injury to health.

Subsection.Text: The person shall notify the Minister without delay of any change to the information referred to in paragraph (1)(j).
The person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before beginning the recall, provide the Minister with a copy of any communications that the person intends to use in connection with beginning the recall; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after beginning the recall, provide the Minister with, on request and within the time specified by the Minister, a copy of any additional communications that the person uses, or intends to use in connection with the recall.

Subsection.Text: The person shall notify the Minister in writing, within 24 hours, of the beginning and completion of the recall.
The person shall, within 30 days after completing the recall, provide the Minister with the following information in writing:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the recall; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the action taken to prevent a recurrence of the problem.

Section.Text: A manufacturer or importer of a medical device who recalls the device without being ordered to do so by the Minister shall keep a record of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a document that sets out the decision to conduct the recall, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and title of the individual who made the decision, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date the decision was made;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date the recall was completed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the information and documents referred to in sections 63.2, 64 and 65; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the document provided to the Minister under subsection 65.1(2), if applicable.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a distributor of a medical device who conducts a recall of the device that was not ordered by the Minister shall keep a record of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identifier of the device, including the identifier of any medical device that is part of a system, test kit, medical device group, medical device family or medical device group family;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a licensed device, the medical device licence number;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a device for which the manufacturer holds an authorization issued under section 68.12, the authorization number;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the establishment where the device was manufactured, if different from that of the manufacturer,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the importer, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the person who sold them the device;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the recall, the nature of the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the device and the date on which and circumstances under which the defectiveness or potential defectiveness was discovered;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the number of affected units of the device that the distributor sold in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the affected units of the device were distributed in Canada by the distributor;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each person to whom the affected device was sold by the distributor and the number of units of the device sold to each person;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any communication issued with respect to the recall;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the results of the recall; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the date the recall was completed.

Subsection.Text: A distributor who initiates the recall shall keep a record of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information and documents referred to in subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evaluation of the risk associated with the defectiveness or potential defectiveness of the medical device to which the recall relates; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the actions that were proposed and actions taken to prevent a recurrence of the problem.

Section.Text: A person who is ordered by the Minister to recall a medical device shall keep a record of the information and documents provided to the Minister under section 65.2.

Subsection.Text: A manufacturer who is required to keep a record under section 65.3 or 65.5 shall keep it for at least the longer of the following periods:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the period that is equivalent to the projected useful life of the medical device to which the recall relates plus two years; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the period during which the device is sold in Canada.

Subsection.Text: Any other person who is required to keep a record under section 65.3, 65.4 or 65.5 shall keep it for at least a period equivalent to the projected useful life of the device to which the recall relates plus two years.
For the purpose of paragraph (1)(a) and subsection (2), the retention period begins on the day on which the recall is completed.

Paragraph 88(d) of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Text: sections 63 to 65.6 with respect to recalls; and

Section.Text: Unless the context requires otherwise, the words and expressions used in sections 22 and 23 have the same meaning as in the Medical Devices Regulations.

A person who has submitted an application for an establishment licence under section 45 of the Medical Devices Regulations before the day on which section 7 comes into force and in respect of which no decision has been made before that day must not be issued the licence unless, by that day and in the form established by the Minister, the person provides the Minister with the information referred to in paragraph 45(b) of the Medical Devices Regulations, as amended by these Regulations.

The holder of an establishment licence that was issued under section 46 of the Medical Devices Regulations before the day on which section 7 comes into force must, by that day and in the form established by the Minister, provide the Minister with the contact information, other than the telephone number, of the representative of the establishment to contact for information concerning the licence.
Subsections 36(2) to (4) of the Medical Devices Regulations2 are replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, at any time, impose terms and conditions on a medical device licence or amend such terms and conditions after considering

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether there are uncertainties relating to the benefits or risks associated with the device;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the requirements under the Act are sufficient for the following objectives to be met:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: maintaining the safety and effectiveness of the device,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: optimizing the benefits and managing the risks associated with the device, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: identifying any changes relating to those benefits and risks and managing uncertainties related to the benefits and risks;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the proposed terms and conditions may contribute to those objectives being met;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether compliance with the proposed terms and conditions is technically feasible; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether there are less burdensome ways for those objectives to be met.

Section.Text: Section 37 of the Regulations is replaced by the following:

If the terms and conditions of a medical device licence for an in vitro diagnostic device require that tests be performed to ensure that the device continues to meet the applicable requirements set out in sections 10 to 20, no person shall sell a device from a lot of the in vitro diagnostic device unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the results and protocols of the tests performed on devices in the lot have been provided to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister determines, on the basis of the results and protocols provided that the devices in the lot continue to meet the applicable requirements set out in sections 10 to 20.

Section.Text: Any terms and conditions that, immediately before the day on which section 41 of these Regulations comes into force, are set out in a medical device licence referred to in subsection 36(1) of the Medical Devices Regulations are deemed to be imposed by the Minister under subsection 36(2) of the Medical Devices Regulations, as that subsection reads as of that day.
